  physical_appearance: This is a black-and-white postcard. The postcard features a print of a painting. The painting depicts a woman sitting on a chair
 with a baby in a cradle on her lap. The title of the painting and the name of the artist is printed below. There are no tears seen on the postcard
 with slight folds at the corners.

  subject_terms_1: correspondence

 B. J. (Bernardus Johannes)
 1845-1914 Postcards

  sgcool_label_text: Alan Oei (b. 1976
 Singapore) is an artist-curator interested in the workings between art history
 politics and community. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia
 Hong Kong
 Melbourne and New York. In addition
 Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’
 an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation
 Singapore. In effect
 Huang Wei may be regarded as a performance on several levels
 and the relationship between creator and created echoes that of a two-way mirror. On one side
 the character of Huang Wei is a conduit and device for Oei to unravel his conundrum about time and history. Yet to ‘use’ Huang Wei entails Oei becoming a medium himself and ‘channelling’ his creation so that the meta-artist can step through time’s portals and enter a realm where history painting still reigns. Still
 even liminal spaces offer fleeting refuge and the stop-motion video Goliath unfolds to reveal the artist’s hand (Huang Wei
 and/or Oei?) in a continuous cycle of creating-destroying his painting
 time and again. In 2009
 the local art public found – to its surprise – that a Singaporean painter active in the Nanyang period had escaped recognition from history books despite leaving behind 76 notable paintings. It was later revealed that Huang Wei never existed – at least not in real life – but was a fiction created by artist-curator Alan Oei. Oei has an enduring fixation with history painting but is troubled that it possesses pale relevance to art-making in the present day. In Huang Wei
 Oei entwined fiction with fact and created a character who stands as a metaphor for a vital but missing part of Singapore’s art history.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a black-and-white postcard. The postcard features a print of a painting. The painting depicts a woman sitting on a chair, with a baby in a cradle on her lap. The title of the painting and the name of the artist is printed below. There are no tears seen on the postcard, with slight folds at the corners.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Alan Oei (b. 1976, Singapore) is an artist-curator interested in the workings between art history, politics and community. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Melbourne and New York. In addition, Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’, an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation, Singapore. In effect, Huang Wei may be regarded as a performance on several levels, and the relationship between creator and created echoes that of a two-way mirror. On one side, the character of Huang Wei is a conduit and device for Oei to unravel his conundrum about time and history. Yet to ‘use’ Huang Wei entails Oei becoming a medium himself and ‘channelling’ his creation so that the meta-artist can step through time’s portals and enter a realm where history painting still reigns. Still, even liminal spaces offer fleeting refuge and the stop-motion video Goliath unfolds to reveal the artist’s hand (Huang Wei, and/or Oei?) in a continuous cycle of creating-destroying his painting, time and again. In 2009, the local art public found – to its surprise – that a Singaporean painter active in the Nanyang period had escaped recognition from history books despite leaving behind 76 notable paintings. It was later revealed that Huang Wei never existed – at least not in real life – but was a fiction created by artist-curator Alan Oei. Oei has an enduring fixation with history painting but is troubled that it possesses pale relevance to art-making in the present day. In Huang Wei, Oei entwined fiction with fact and created a character who stands as a metaphor for a vital but missing part of Singapore’s art history.
